title: Diabetes Management and Education I
requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • Overview of pathophysiology, diagnosis and management of diabetes mellitus with particular emphasis on application of knowledge and acquisition of practical skills.• Importance of patient education and multi-disciplinary management to achieve quality care for prevention and control of diabetes and its complications.

title: Diabetes Management and Education II
requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • Overview of pathophysiology, diagnosis and management of energy metabolism including obesity and diabetic complications and its comorbidities • Importance of using a multi-disciplinary approach to manage complexity and empower self-management

title: General Endocrinology and Metabolism I
requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • Pathophysiology of the endocrine system and principles underlying the maintenance of homeostasis in human body • The effects of environment and lifestyles on mental and physical health and the neurohormonal and metabolic basis for the clinical manifestation of diseases• Clinical approach including diagnosis, assessment and management of patients with endocrine and metabolic diseases

title: General Endocrinology and Metabolism II
requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • Pathophysiology of the endocrine system and principles underlying the maintenance of homeostasis in human body• The effects of environment and lifestyles on mental and physical health and the neurohormonal and metabolic basis for the clinical manifestation of diseases• Clinical approach including diagnosis, assessment and management of patients with endocrine and metabolic diseases
outcome: • Overview of the interconnectivity of different pathways within the neuroendocrine system with diverse clinical presentations  • Know the clinical features and basic principles for management of adrenal, growth and reproductive disorders including special needs in children and pregnant women • Understand the hormonal responses and pitfalls in data interpretation and hormonal replacement during critical illnesses  • Recognize the importance of using a multidisciplinary, multi-method and multi-staged approach to diagnose and localize an endocrine disorder as well as the short and long term management including monitoring and hormone replacement
syllabus: • 12 lectures in 4 seminars and 3 interactive workshops explaining the epidemiology, clinical presentation, investigations and management of various endocrine disorders including adrenal glands, growth and reproduction  • 5 clinical attachments including ward rounds and outpatient clinic visits to appreciate the clinical diversity of endocrine disorders

title: Obesity and Weight Management
requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • Overview of epidemiology, medical hazards and management of obesity with particular emphasis on application of knowledge to implement multidisciplinary care• Interplay between neurohormonal regulation and cognitive- psychological-behavioral abnormalities in obesity• The assessments and inter-dependence between body composition, physical fitness and metabolic rate
outcome: • Learn the epidemiology, classification and multiple morbidities associated with obesity • Understand the scientific principles underlying regulation of energy metabolism by multiple organs including brain, gut, liver, muscle, pancreas and adipose tissues  • Recognize the past, present and future strategies for weight management including pharmacological, non-pharmacological and behavioral interventions • Appreciate the evidence base and utility of different diets and exercise programs in weight management • Know the latest recommendations and controversies regarding surgical treatment for obesity and after care
syllabus: • 2 seminars with 6 lectures illustrating the principles of diagnosis, pathophysiology and treatment of obesity • 2 interactive workshops illustrating the practical management of obesity including exercise, diet, drugs, surgery and behavioral therapy

requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • Introduction on how to conduct research, critique literature and use research results in clinical practice

title: General Endocrinology and Metabolism III
requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • Pathophysiology of the endocrine system and principles underlying the maintenance of homeostasis in human body• The effects of environment and lifestyles on mental and physical health and the neurohormonal and metabolic basis for the clinical manifestation of diseases• Clinical approach including diagnosis, assessment and management of patients with endocrine and metabolic diseases
outcome: • Understand the mechanisms underlying common often symptomatic endocrine/metabolic disorders manifested as electrolyte and lipid abnormalities • Recognize endocrine causes for abnormal growth and reproduction as well as dysregulation of sex hormones and how to order investigations and interpret results for appropriate clinical decisions
syllabus: • 2 interactive workshops explaining the regulation of electrolyte control and lipid metabolism as well as the regulation of growth hormone and sex steroids in determining growth and reproduction  • 1 clinical attachment to combined clinic to appreciate the clinical presentation of common gynecological and growth problems

title: Graduation Project
requirements: For students in MSc Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism
description: • A 5,000-word research-based dissertation involving protocol writing up, data analysis and reporting of results and discussion on a topic related to endocrinology, diabetes or metabolic medicine
outcome: • Apply theoretical and experiential learning skills to formulate a research question relevant to obesity, diabetes and/or endocrine disorder with regards to diagnosis, prognosis, causation and therapy
syllabus: • Formulate a hypothesis, explain its rationale and use a local database to analyse, interpret and report the results with conclusions, limitations and future directions relevant to the course
